stories.text:
hi I'm desperate to do something interesting or useful it shouldn't be too easy because you can google it it shouldn't take too long because I easily get bored

if I need to I can read any documentation or paper I can debug or program in any programming language I can learn inkscape or krita or blender or godot or Unity

any idea is welcome thanks
stories.title: Ask HN: Can you give me something interesting or useful to work on?

stories.text:
Since the Bay Area is probably represented here more than other areas, I just want to give you all a head's up:

There is a reddit dev in the Bay Area sub who will shadowban you site-wide and set your a disagreeable sub to always show when you click "Random", and who-knows what else.

Last night there was a post in the Bay Area subreddit about "tire deflators" (there was even a long HN discussion about it the other day). Apparently it struck a nerve with a reddit dev there and they've retaliated.

I first posted about it here: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=32010005

It seems like it was fixed, but now the issue is back, and "Random" goes to another weird sub that I've never been to before.
stories.title: Tell HN: Bay Area Reddit Dev is abusing privileges
Lightweight event manager and dispatcher implements by Go

stories.text: Why don't more companies take advantage of existing mechanisms for authentication via public key, e.g. using SSH as a way to interface with SaaS/web services? Some reasons that come to mind are a) most people don't know how to create and share a public key and b) there isn't very good integration between public keys and browsers, which are obviously necessary to use services that have complex GUIs. But given the benefit of not having to rely on a third party identity provider like Google, why aren't there more people focused on solving those problems?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why hasn't the public key taken off as a general identity mgmt solution?
